intro: Aster hyssopifolius var. hirtus, commonly known as the hairy aster, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy, lance-shaped leaves that are often grayish-green in color. Its showy blue to purple flowers bloom in late summer to early fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The hairy aster is well adapted to dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and grasslands.
